pros:
- Best in class HR policies, generous pay and progressive benefits structure
- Absolutely wonderful people work here
- Leadership is accessible to all staff and they sincerely listen to - and act upon - feedback
- Huge potential for impact that serves our mission
- Everyone is committed to improving the "cons" listed below and are collaborating to create an even brighter future
cons:
- Start-up culture that can feel unfocused because there are so many resources that could be serving many different needs
- Shifting to a virtual work environment has meant less personal connection with each other, which can lead to feelings of isolation
- Major difficulty navigating covid and retaining staff during the unpredictability of the pandemic

pros: Awesome benefits and awesome people to work with. Everyone on the team is super passionate about the work and are true trailblazers.
cons: Lack of systems to share feedback regarding DEI and org culture

review_title: Continuing to make an impact despite pandemic setbacks
pros: Innovative, forward-thinking and mission-driven organization. There is never a doubt in my mind that I am doing impactful work at Upstream. The compensation and benefits package is competitive and generous for a nonprofit. Leadership seems to genuinely care about equitable, diverse, and inclusive workplace practices.
cons: As with every company, there are growing pains. Many tools, systems, and processes are still being built out and fine-tuned. The fast pace is not for everyone.

job_title: Software and Hardware Support Technician in Boston, MA
pros: From day one, everyone at Upstream has been welcoming and kind. The amount of encouragement and support I have felt from my coworkers is incomparable to previous roles. Having a hybrid schedule has made it very easy to form relationships and maintain them both in person and online. And there is no better feeling knowing you are working for an organization with such an amazing mission.
cons: There aren't many cons that I have run into.

pros: The company has a good mission.
cons: Management needs more structure and also needs to valve employees opinions more.

job_title: Director of Talent Development and People Programs in Boston, MA
pros: Centered on the mission, generous salaries, rich growth & development opportunities & no shortage of talented, super bright people to partner with.
cons: Not really a con of Upstream; but more a reality of our current times that we are still operating in a remote environment. It can be very challenging to not have more face-to-face, in person connections with our colleagues, however fortunately we are starting to build back in team events.

pros: Employees really care about the mission. Decent pay.
cons: Upper management (national) is out of touch with the staff. Bad communication and follow through from national. Lack of trust between employees and management
Fluid work environment with constant changes and uncertainties

job_title: Quality Improvement Coordinator in Oakland, CA
pros: Collaborative teams, great work culture, flexible work. CEO is caring and involved.
cons: Its a non-profit, so subject to layoffs.

job_title: Quality Improvement Advisor in Charlotte, NC
cons: Some diversity issues within the teams

pros:
Everyone who works here is so smart, and so dedicated to the mission, it is inspiring.  They are also kind, supportive, fun, joyful, and hilarious. 

The organization is growing fast, which means if you're willing to jump in and get your hands dirty, there are lots of opportunities for growth.

Upper management seems to be sincerely committed to identifying shortcomings and finding ways to improve. I feel respected and valued as an employee, and have plenty of opportunities to contribute ideas to drive my work.
cons:
With so much growth, it can be hard to keep up with all the new names and faces, especially with teams located in different states, and inter-departmental communication is not always the best. 

If you're adverse to change, it may be uncomfortable at times because the change is pretty constant.

job_title: Quality Improvement Coordinator in Boston, MA
pros: Well-resourced nonprofit, good benefits, coworkers are knowledgeable and care about the work.
cons:
Management’s openness to feedback is an illusion, as are its efforts to promote diversity, equity, and inclusion. Patient voices – especially those from communities that have been historically targeted by coercive reproductive healthcare practices – are significantly underrepresented in leadership. I repeatedly witnessed and encountered resistance and retaliation in the workplace when this was called out. It's demoralizing for staff who were hired for their "diverse background" not to see themselves and their experiences reflected in positions of power. Furthermore, it often becomes the responsibility of those same individuals to advocate for their inclusion and growth within the organization.

There are no growth opportunities or workplace flexibility for non-exempt, hourly staff. It’s a top heavy structure, and managers have very little support or training. As the organization expands, more levels of management and bureaucracy are built into teams.

review_title: Rewarding experience and great company culture.
job_title: Women's Health Navigator in Wilmington, DE
pros: Leadership values employee feedback! Upstream USA thinks outside the box which allows top talent to stretch their imaginations.
cons: Upstream USA was a start-up nonprofit so continuous improvement was encouraged & change happened daily.

review_title: One of the best organizations anyone can work for.
pros: People oriented, Mission oriented organization with great benefits that value their employees with open doors and transparent communication.

cons: If you don't like startups, you may not enjoy the pace
